alert.note: Alert for Calhoun; Clarendon; Orangeburg; Sumter (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 29 at 3:01PM EDT by NWS Columbia
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of central South Carolina, including the following areas, Calhoun, Clarendon, Orangeburg and Sumter. * WHEN...Until 500 PM EDT. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Overflowing poor drainage areas. Ponding of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 257 PM EDT, gauge reports indicated heavy rain. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. Between 0.5 and 1 inch of rain has fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Manning, Summerton, Elloree, Santee State Park, Santee Cooper Regional Airport, Alcolu, Santee, Pinewood, Paxville, Vance, St. Paul, Davis Station, Rimini, Poplar Creek Landing, Stumphole Landing, Low Falls Landing, Mill Creek Marina and Campground, Privateer, Indian Bluff Recreation Park and Brogdon. Areas that have received the heaviest rainfall are Upper Sammy and Boggy Swamps, Hungary Ball Branch, Spring Grove Creek near Pinewood and Des Champs Branch. The heaviest rain has fallen in the communities of Pinewood, Paxville and Rimini. - This includes the following highways... Interstate 95 between mile markers 94 and 127. - http://www.floodsafety.noaa.gov
info.instruction: Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads. Most flooding deaths occur in vehicles. Never drive through a flooded roadway or around barricades. Turn around, don`t drown. Report any flooding directly to the Columbia National Weather Service at 803 234 4115 when it is safe to do so. You can also send reports by Facebook or Twitter to NWSColumbia or by e-mail at NWS.Columbia@noaa.gov.
